yeah right so now we get into some nitty-gritty developer level details the
way unity tends to work is that the highest or the biggest concept in unity
3d is the concept of a scene so if you have ever played a computer game you can
the equivalent of a scene is probably a level so when people are designing levels for computer games in unity 3d
there's a good chance that they'll have one Scene per level and basically swap
between scenes and inside of that scene you've got all the things that you might
see in that scene you know enemies good guys bad guys landscape or the all the
rest of it so each one of these scenes unity3d keeps a file if you look inside the file
it's just a text file and it's a it describes the relationship between everything in 3d so this tree might be
at this location that car might be at that location and it'll describe the coordinates of those two relative to
each other unfortunately things are a
little more complicated in as much as that it doesn't actually say car or tree it gives the good of car or tree and if
you've got a reasonably complex scene there's like hundreds of these goods you know do it at this position good link to
that good-good listen to that good so it's it's great big kind of dictionary
or hash table of goods and their associated properties which is usually
a problem but it does have a few unexpected day-to-day consequences the
big one being when you got any more than about and no two or three people on a
project and on this particular project we certainly add to it more than two or three people my apologies I have a a
disease vector into my household aka a five-year-old and my body can't
quite decide whether it wants to play with the latest infection which is sweeping through my household anyway
story at hand so you have one file per scene and for this particular
application we didn't really have any obvious reason to use more than one
scene it's that the user experience is all kind of in one virtual space and
that tends to be with the way with a lot of hololens applications but this one was particularly so there was just no
obvious point to kind of take a cut and move stuff into another scene so that
means we add one sizable file and if you've got a team of 12 20 people all
working on this one file then even with your best source control you're going to
find yourself in a little bit of pain and particularly so with a source file
which is only mildly human readable it's one thing when you're you know just
dealing with the file yourself and you can go okay that good seems to be kind of related to I think that's the tree
okay so it makes sense that I'm replacing the tree or updating the tree or something like that but when you've got 20 people all
mucking around with the one scene file you pretty much hit the nexus of evil
very very quickly and lo and behold that's what happened to us in this team
the Microsoft team this game studio launch vector they usually have much smaller team
sizes this one was a bit of a unique set of circumstances so even it was
while they had experience kind of merge Hill before this was kind of two or three times their regular merge Hill so
it was a bit of a unique experience for them as well the solution to this as you
might guess is to break that up into multiple files so that you've got an even better chance of basically one
person working on their own little bit at any one time the way that you achieve this in unity for the most part is
through things called prefabs so prefabs are like a little bit of scene all by
themselves you you can say okay this
tree and that chipmunk and those nuts in the tree and so forth I'll put them all in this little prefab and when so when
that gets referred to in the scene it's just one little entry I can go work on that tree and it'll go and all the
changes will go into its own file so that that solved a fair amount of the
pain it didn't kind of obliterate it completely I still like personally
merging unity files is not one of my my strong suits apparently I'm just not
that smart so I still encountered some a
bit of merge hell a bit of merge pain myself but yeah for 20 people we went
from being absolutely kind of locked in for hours at a time trying to resolve
these things into some sort of rolling level of progress okay

unity we were lucky enough time wise that unity I think it might have been
literally that week or week previously had just released a new bit of functionality into beta testing if
memory serves I think it's called director and director as its name might
hint at was one of the first major attempts by unity to break it out into a
new market so they had been quite successful to say the least with capturing game developers and if
basically anything that's not a triple-a title there's a very very very good

to basically try and produce a series of films using unity3d and by using mocap and hide all sorts of
you know full-on Hollywood level production all going
through the the unity app and one of the things that the the film people their
feedback back to unity was well this is all fine but this whole animation system
is really still geared towards game developers if I want to do a run cycle and you know the character delete me
over a log and then continue running the animation system works brilliantly for that but if I've got you know six
minutes of an actor strolling around a room delivering a monologue and and I
need to capture the nuances of the face and I need to be able to mix and match edits so that I can get take two of the
factor and take six of that actor and have it all seamlessly work together unity is not really supporting me in
that so one of unities responses to that was this director feature and really
director is as its name suggests it's just a higher level of abstraction with
director you can basically grab a bunch of animations together on a timeline and voila problem
solved now for us we wanted to make use of director but we also wanted to kind
of break it a bit so we didn't want one big continuous bit of and non interactive sets of animations because
then it wouldn't be a NAPA would just kind of be a movie which is perfectly good but not what we were aiming for so
we decided upon having a bunch of directors basically a director for each
little mini ARS that scene without getting to the confusing you'd have one director taking care of the introduction
and then another director taking care of whatever you know part one of the story was and then so on so on and that that
worked reasonably well these days director is a lot more solid but in
those days it was very very much a better product it had its own set of
quirks and they weren't quirks in areas that you ever really wanted so
if your little stretcher animation happened to include a bit of animation
that's repeated right at the end then director would kind of get a little confused and it was a 50/50 chance
whether that animation played or played continuously or played wrong or stuff like that so it took a whole lot of fine-tuning to
make a director work that we want the way we wanted to and it was it felt kind of like black magic oh you can't have
you know a whole number here it's got to be a partial number here for no obvious reason so that was a bit of an
interesting experience okay these days
these days year director is a pretty solid choice for orchestrating
animations if you need animations that aren't reliant themselves on interaction
with what the users doing and director is a very very good choice if you need things that are reacting to the user in
real time then unities traditional animation system does just fine okay
